question: Who said first : “Swaraj is my birth right and I shall have it”.............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Bal Gangadhar Tilak
option_2: M.K. Gandhi
option_3: Lala Lajpat Rai
option_4: Sardar Patel
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Bal Gangadhar Tilak, a freedom activist and social reformer, is credited with saying “Swaraj is my birthright, and I shall have it”. Tilak was a radical nationalist and social conservative who popularized the concepts of Swaraj, Swadeshi, national education, and boycott.
  • Tilak’s activism, which appealed to Hindu symbolism and Maratha history, brought him into conflict with the British government. He was tried for sedition three times, and his prosecution only gained him more popularity. He earned the title Lokamanya, which means “Beloved Leader of the People”. Tilak died on August 1, 1920 in Mumbai.

question: First Europeans, who started trade with India, were............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: The Portuguese
option_2: The British
option_3: The French
option_4: The Dutch
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Portugal was the first European country to try to find a sea route to India. In 1498, Vasco da Gama successfully reached Calicut, India, and was welcomed by the King Zamorin. In 1501, Vasco da Gama returned to India and established a trading center in Cannanore.
  • The Portuguese established trading settlements in Calicut, Cochin, and Cannanore. The Portuguese Companywas the first European trading company to establish trade posts in India. They established trading settlements in Cochin, Goa, Daman and Diu, Salsette and Bassein, and Bombay.
  • The Portuguese East India Company was established in 1501, when Vasco da Gama set up a trading center in Cannanore. The Portuguese then established factories in Calicut and Cochin.
  • The Portuguese were the first Europeans to arrive in India in 1498, followed by the Dutch in 1605, the British in 1612, and the French in 1667. The Danes arrived in 1620.

question: “India Wins Freedom” was written by............ (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Rajendra Prasad
option_2: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad
option_3: R.N. Tagore
option_4: J. L Nehru
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Maulana Abul Kalam Azad wrote India Wins Freedom. The book is about Azad’s political journey and his perspective on the partition of India. It includes his personal experiences and his ideas on freedom and liberty.
  • Azad was president of the All India National Congress twice, serving from 1940–1946. After partition, he became India’s Education Minister.
  • Azad was born in Mecca in 1888. His narrative was influenced by his Islamic upbringing, liberal ideas, and commitment to the nation.

question: The cause for the immediate precipitation of the Sepoy Mutiny was............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Use of cartridges greased with cow fat
option_2: Doctrine of Lapse
option_3: The disparity between salaries of Native Sepoys and the British Soldiers
option_4: The Spread of Christianity
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Sepoy Mutiny, also known as the Indian Mutiny, was a revolt by Indian soldiers against their British commanders in 1857-58. The rebellion began in Meerut on May 10, 1857, when sepoys of the British East India Company's army mutinied.
  • The rebellion spread to other areas, including Delhi, Kanpur, Agra, and Lucknow. The rebellion was contained in 1858 when the rebels were defeated in Gwalior on June 20.
  • The rebellion was a response to the British East India Company's attempts to develop the Indian economy and legal system. In January 1857, rumors began to circulate in the army that cartridges had been greased with animal tallow, which is sacred to Hindus and pigs being forbidden for Muslims. 
  • The process for opening a cartridge was to tear the paper seal with your teeth, which some boys found to be a sin and an attempt to undermine their religions.
  • The British granted amnesty to all rebels not involved in murder on November 1, 1858, but did not declare the hostilities to have formally ended until July 8, 1859.
  • British Administration records say that about 6,000 British died in the Indian Mutiny, and 800,000 Indians, including those who died during the mutiny, famines, and epidemics.

The Doctrine of Lapse :

  • It was a policy that stated that if an Indian ruler died without a male heir, their kingdom would automatically become part of the British Empire. The policy was introduced by Lord Dalhousie, the Governor General of India from 1848 to 1856. The doctrine was also applied in cases where the ruler was judged to be "unfit" to rule.
  • The Doctrine of Lapse was one of the methods of the East India Company to expand its territory. The doctrine was also applied by the East India Company in India until 1859. The first state annexed under the doctrine of lapse was Satara in 1848.
  • The Doctrine of Lapse is generally regarded as having contributed to the discontent that was a factor in the outbreak of the Indian Mutiny in 1857 and the widespread revolt that followed.

question: The Home Rule movement was launched by............ (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: G.K. Gokhale
option_2: Bal Gangadhar Tilak
option_3: Mahatma Gandhi
option_4: Lala Lajpat Rai
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Indian Home Rule movement was founded by Annie Besant and Bal Gangadhar Tilak. The movement was part of the Indian independence movement and lasted from 1916–1918. The movement’s goal was to gain home rule or dominion status for India under the British Empire.
  • The term “home rule” was borrowed from a similar movement in Ireland. The Home Rule League was established in April and September 1916, respectively, by Tilak and Besant. The movement is believed to have set the stage for the independence movement for the educated English speaking upper class Indians.
  • The purpose of the advocates of home rule was to encourage people to participate in the freedom movement. Home rule refers to the concept of self-government or autonomy at the local level.

question: Gandhiji’s “Champaran Movement” was for............ (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: The security of rights of Harijans
option_2: Civil disobedience movement
option_3: Maintaining the unity of Hindu society
option_4: Solving the problem of the Indigo workers
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Champaran Satyagraha was a nonviolent resistance campaign led by Mahatma Gandhi in 1917. The movement was a protest against the exploitation andabuse faced by local indigo farmers at the hands of the British colonial authorities and plantation owners.
  • The Champaran Satyagraha was the first popular satyagraha movement. It was a peasants uprising, led by Mahatma Gandhi in the Champaran district of Bihar. The farmer’s in the region revolted against the British power against the imposed indigo cultivation between 1914 and 1916.
  • The movement was started by Mahatma Gandhi in 1917 to look into the problem of the Tinkathia system. Under this system, the tenant farmers were compelled to grow indigo on a specific portion of their landholding. This was typically 3/20th of their land.
  • During the Champaran Satyagraha movement, Mahatma Gandhi was arrested on 16th April 1917 on the charges of creating deep unrest and was ordered to evacuate the province.

The Civil Disobedience Movement (CDM) :

  • It was a major mass movement launched in 1930 by Mahatma Gandhi.

The CDM’s demands included:

1. Releasing political prisoners

2. Reducing the rupee-sterling exchange ratio

3. Reducing agricultural tax by 50%

4. Eliminating the government’s monopoly on salt

5. Reducing military expenditure and salaries of highest-grade services

  • The CDM was withdrawn in 1931 when Gandhi signed the “Gandhi-Irwin” pact.
  • Civil disobedience is a nonviolent action where an individual refuses to obey a law for moral or philosophical reasons. It can be active or passive, direct or indirect. The purpose of civil disobedience is usually to force concessions from the government or occupying power.

Some examples of civil disobedience include:

1. The Boston Tea Party

2. Mahatma Gandhi’s Salt March

3. Suffragists’ illegal voting

4. Whites-only lunch counter sit-ins

5. Youth climate movement school walkouts

Civil disobedience is also known as passive resistance. It has been a major tactic and philosophy of many social movements, including:

1. Nationalist movements in Africa and India

2. The American civil rights movement

3. Labor movements

question: Gandhiji started Dandi March in 1930............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Against imposition of salt tax laws
option_2: Against the announcement of communal award
option_3: Against atrocities committed on Harijans
option_4: Against all of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Mahatma Gandhi started the Dandi March on March 12, 1930. The march lasted until April 6, 1930. The Dandi March, also known as the Salt March and the Dandi Satyagraha, was a nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly.
  • The march was a direct action campaign of tax resistance and protest against injustice. The march began at Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad and ended in Dandi, a coastal town in Gujarat. The march was nearly 385 km long and Gandhi was accompanied by 80 satyagrahis.
  • Gandhi inaugurated the Civil Disobedience Movement by picking up a handful of salt in Dandi. He continued his satyagraha against the salt tax for the next two months, encouraging other Indians to break the salt laws.

The Communal Award :

  • It was a series of elections announced by British Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonaldon August 16, 1932. It was also known as the MacDonald Award. The award was a result of the second round table conference and was based on the findings of the Indian Franchise Committee.

The key provisions of the award were:

1. Doubling the seats in the provincial legislatures

2. Keeping the separate electorate system, especially for minorities

3. Providing considerable weightage to the Muslims

4. Reserving 3% of the total seats for women

  • The Communal Award extended the separate electorate to depressed classes and other minorities, including Muslims, Sikhs, Indian Christians, Anglo-Indians, and Europeans. The award favored the minorities over the Hindus, causing consternation and anger from Gandhi.

question: “Khilafat” movement subsided because of the............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Concessions given to Muslims by the British
option_2: Amity achieved between Congress and Muslim League
option_3: Accession of Kamal Pasha on the throne of Turkey
option_4: None of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Khilafat Movement, which lasted from 1919–1924, lost its momentum when Mustafa Kemal Pasha dethroned the Turkish Sultan in 1922 and declared Turkey a secular republic. The movement collapsed in 1924 when Atatürk abolished the caliphate. The Khilafat Movement was a movement by Indian Muslims to pressure the British government to preserve the authority of the Ottoman Sultan as Caliph of Islam. The movement was led by Mohammad Ali and Shaukat Ali, known as the Ali brothers, along with Mahatma Gandhi. Themovement’s goal was to unite the Muslim community under a unified national movement.

question: Who commented “the Cripps Mission was a postdated cheque on a crashing bank”? (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Mahatma Gandhi
option_2: Jawaharlal Nehru
option_3: Subhash Chandra Bose
option_4: Sardar Patel
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • In 1942, Mahatma Gandhi called the Cripps Mission’s proposal of dominion status a “post-dated cheque drawn on a crashing bank”. The Cripps Mission was a British government proposal to seek Indian cooperation during World War II. From March 22 to April 11, 1942, Stafford Cripps, a member of the War Cabinet, visited India to discuss the British Government’s Draft Declaration on the Constitution of India with Indian leaders. The Mission declared that India would be a Dominion and that an elected body would frame its constitution after the war. Gandhi’s statement led to the Congress Party stopping talks and demanding self government in exchange for war support. The talks failed, and the British PM, Viceroy, and Commander-in-chief were consistently against Cripps’ efforts.

question: The Lucknow Congress Session of 1916 refers to............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Concession of separate electorates for the Muslims by the Congress Party
option_2: Merger of Muslim League into Congress
option_3: Selection of Muslim leader as the Congress President
option_4: None of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Lucknow Congress Session of 1916 is known for the Lucknow Pact, which was signed between the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League in December 1916.

The pact included the following provisions:

1. The Congress agreed to separate electorates for Muslims in provincial council elections.

2. The Congress agreed to give Muslims one-third representation in the state government.

3. The Congress agreed to weightage the favor of Muslims in all provinces except the Punjab and Bengal.

The pact included other reforms, such as:

i. Self-government in India

ii. Abolition of the Indian Council

iii. Separation of the executive from the judiciary

iv. Salaries of the Secretary of State for Indian Affairs to be paid from British coffers and not the Indian funds

  • The 1916 session also led to the readmission of the extremists to the Congress.

question: The aim of the Cripps Mission to India was to.............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Appease the Indian public opinion
option_2: Appease the American people
option_3: Decentralise the power to States
option_4: None of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Cripps Mission was a failed attempt by the British government in 1942 to gain Indian support for their efforts in World War II. The mission was led by Sir Richard Stafford Cripps, a labor minister in Winston Churchill’s coalition government. The mission was in India from March 22 to April 11, 1942.

The mission’s objectives included:

1. Obtaining Indian cooperation for the British war efforts

2. Securing Indian cooperation and support for the British war

3. Establishing the Indian Union and the status of domination

4. Appeasing the Indian public opinion

5. Ensuring India would be free to decide its relations with the Common wealth

  • The mission also proposed that after the war, a constituent assembly would be convened to create a new constitution. The assembly’s members would be partly elected by the provincial assemblies and partly nominated by the princes.

question: The Interim Government at the Centre after independence was formed............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: After the visit of Cripps Mission
option_2: Before the visit of Cripps Mission
option_3: After Mountbatten submitted his plan
option_4: Before the visit of the Cabinet Mission
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Interim Government of India was formed on September 2, 1946, after the Cabinet Mission of Britain visited India in 1946. The Cabinet Mission was part of the Cabinet Mission Plan of 1946, which was an attempt by the British government to address tensions between the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League over the future of India.
  • The Cripps Mission began in 1942, and colonial authorities made several attempts to form an interim government in India.

The Cripps Mission’s proposals included:

1. Setting up an Indian dominion Forming a Constituent

2. Assembly to frame a new constitution

3. Allowing any province that was unwilling to join the Indian dominion to form a separate union and have a separate constitution

  • The Cabinet Mission’s proposals failed because the Congress Party wanted a strong center with minimal powers for the provinces, and the Muslim League wanted strong political safeguards for Muslims. The interim government was formed from the newly elected Constituent Assembly on September 2, 1946. The government included the Viceroy and Commander in Chief of Britain, members from the AllIndia Muslim League, and Jawaharlal Nehru as the Head of the Interim Government.

The Mountbatten Plan :

  • It is also known as the 3 June Plan, was a proposal to divide British India into India and Pakistan. It was announced on June 3, 1947, and led to the end of British colonial rule in the Indian subcontinent. The plan’s main purpose was to partition India and quickly transfer responsibility to Indian governments for the divided sections.

The plan included the following principles:

1. Both countries would have the right to make their own constitutions.

2. Both countries would have autonomy and sovereignty.

3. Princely states would have the choice to remain independent or join India or Pakistan.

  • The Boundary Commission was established to fix the international boundaries between the two countries. The commission was chaired by Sir Cyril Radcliffe and was tasked with demarcating Bengal and Punjab into the two new countries.
  • The Indian Independence Act was passed by the British parliament on July 5, 1947. The act’s aim was to transfer power from the British Crown to the newly independent dominions of India and Pakistan.

The Cabinet Mission Plan :

  • It was a statement made in 1946 by the British Prime Minister Clement Attlee to discuss the transfer of power from the British to the Indian government. The plan proposed a three-tier administrative structure for British India.

The plan also aimed to:

1. Strengthen India’s unity

2. Help India achieve independence

3. Avoid partition

  • The plan proposed the formation of a Union of India, comprising both the British India and the Princely States. The Union would remain in charge of only foreign affairs, defense, and communications.
  • The plan failed due to a conflict : of interest between the Hindu and Muslim groups. The Congress opposed the creation of Pakistan as the Cabinet Mission Plan did not guarantee a separate sovereign state for Muslims.

question: Rabindranath Tagore surrendered his title to the British because of............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Civil Disobedience Movement
option_2: Non Cooperation Movement
option_3: Jallianwalah Bagh massacre
option_4: Partition of Bengal
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Rabindranath Tagore returned his knighthood in 1919 to protest the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.
  • In 1915, King George V awarded Tagore a knighthood for his contributions to literature, making him the first Indian to receive the honor. On April 13, 1919, General Dyer and his armed troops opened fire on a crowd of thousands gathered at Jallianwala Bagh in Amritsar. Tagore renounced his knighthood in 1919 to condemn the incident.
  • Tagore received news of the massacre on May 22, 1919. He attempted to organize a protest meeting in Calcutta before deciding to renounce his knighthood as a symbolic act of protest.

The Civil Disobedience Movement (CDM) :

  • It was a major mass movement launched in 1930 by Mahatma Gandhi.

The CDM’s demands included:

1. Releasing political prisoners

2. Reducing the rupee-sterling exchange ratio

3. Reducing agricultural tax by 50%

4. Eliminating the government’s monopoly on salt

5. Reducing military expenditure and salaries of highest-grade services

  • The CDM was withdrawn in 1931 when Gandhi signed the “Gandhi-Irwin” pact.
  • Civil disobedience is a nonviolent action where an individual refuses to obey a law for moral or philosophical reasons. It can be active or passive, direct or indirect. The purpose of civil disobedience is usually to force concessions from the government or occupying power.

Some examples of civil disobedience include:

1. The Boston Tea Party

2. Mahatma Gandhi’s Salt March

3. Suffragists’ illegal voting

4. Whites-only lunch counter sit-ins

5. Youth climate movement school walkouts

Civil disobedience is also known as passive resistance. It has been a major tactic and philosophy of many social movements, including:

1. Nationalist movements in Africa and India

2. The American civil rights movement

3. Labor movements

4. Anti-war movements

The Non-Cooperation Movement :

  • It was a peaceful protest against the British government in India that lasted from 1920 to 1922. The movement was a political campaign led by Mahatma Gandhi to persuade the British to grant self-governance to India. The movement’s main goal was to achieve “Poorna swaraj” through peaceful means.

The movement was triggered by many reasons, including:

  • The Jallianwala Bagh massacre On April 13, 1919, a large crowd of unarmed men, women, and children were shot at with machine guns and rifles by General Dyer.
  • The Government of India Act of 1919
  • This act curtailed the right to vote and gave Indians little say in government decisions.
  • Resentment at the British after the war
  • Indians felt betrayed by the British after they provided extensive support of manpower and resources during the First World War.

The movement consisted of Indians:

1. Resigning their titles

2. Boycotting government educational institutions, the courts, government service, foreign goods, and elections

3. Eventually, refusing to pay taxes

  • The British government responded with severe repression, arresting thousands of protesters and imposing harsh punishments. This led to further resentment and fueled the demand for independence.

The Partition of Bengal :

  • It was a territorial reorganization of the Bengal Presidency that took place on October 16, 1905. The British Raj implemented the partition, which separated the largely Hindu western areas from the largely Muslim eastern areas.
  • The partition divided the province into West Bengal and East Bengal. The Muslims supported the partition because they would have their own province, but the Hindus opposed it.
  • T he partition led to a nationalist movement known as the Swadeshi Movement. The movement advocated boycotting British goods and promoting Indian-made products to protest against the partition and assert Indian self-reliance.
  • The partition also brought the province to the brink of open rebellion. The British recognized that Bengal was too large for a single province and determined that it needed reorganization and division.

question: Who led the extremists before the arrival of Gandhiji on the political scene for freedom struggle? (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Bal Gangadhar Tilak
option_2: Dadabhai Naoroji
option_3: Gopal Krishna Gokhale
option_4: Subhash Bose
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Dadabhai Naoroji And Gopal Krishna Gokhale belong to moderates and not extremist leaders. While Subhash Bose entered into struggle only after Gandhian entry. Before Mahatma Gandhi, Bal Gangadhar Tilak was the most popular leader of the Indian freedom struggle.
  • Tilak was an extremist who used extremist methods to achieve freedom. He protested against the British government and advocated self rule, or Swaraj.

Other prominent extremist leaders include:

1. Bipin Chandra Pal

2. Lala Lajpat Rai

3. Aurobindo Ghosh Extremists believed in agitation, strikes, and boycotts to force their demands.

  • Moderates, on the other hand, believed in constitutional methods of protests like petitions, prayers, and meetings. The differences between the moderates and the extremists became official in the Surat session of the Indian National Congress (INC) in 1907.

question: Who was the Prime Minister of U.K. at the time of India’s Independence? (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Lord Attlee
option_2: Winston Churchill
option_3: Lord Mountbatten
option_4: Harold Wilson
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Clement Attlee was the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom when India gained independence in 1947. Attlee was the leader of the Labour Party from 1935 to 1955, and served as Prime Minister from 1945 to 1951.
  • On July 4, 1947, Attlee introduced the Indian Independence Bill in the House of Commons. Both houses of the British Parliament passed the bill on July 15, 1947.
  • On February 20, 1947, Attlee announced in the House of Commons that the British would leave India by June 30, 1948. India’s independence in 1947 was the result of years of nonviolent resistance to British rule, led by Mohandas Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru.

question: Indian National Congress took the stand during Second World War that.............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: It would support axis powers
option_2: It would support allied powers
option_3: It would cooperate with the British if India is promised dominion status after the war
option_4: It would cooperate with the British if India is granted complete Independence
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Indian National Congress (INC) took the stand during World War II to demand complete independence from the British.

The Indian National Congress (INC) took a stand during World War II in the following ways:

1. Declared independence :

  • The INC declared that India was ready to work with the British in World War II, but only if the British immediately granted India complete independence. The INC also demanded the establishment of a national government.

2. Refused to cooperate :

  • In August 1942, the INC launched the Quit India Movement, refusing to cooperate with the government until India was granted independence.

3. Planned civil disobedience :

  • The INC planned a civil disobedience campaign against the war, but its leaders were arrested before it could begin.

4. Supported mass civil disobedience :

  • In 1942, the INC sponsored mass civil disobedience to support the demand that the British “quit India”

question: The French supremacy in India came to an end with the.............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Battle of Wandiwash
option_2: Battle of Plassey
option_3: Battle of Buxar
option_4: Battle of Panipat
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Battle of Wandiwash in 1760 marked the end of French influence in India. The battle was fought between the British, led by Eyre Coote, and the French, led by T homas-Arthur, Comte de Lally.
  • The battle was a decisive victory for the British, who defeated the French and captured Marquis de Bussy. The French put up a fierce resistance, but were overwhelmed by the British’s superior tactics and firepower.
  • The Battle of Wandiwash was a decisive battle in the Third Carnatic War, which ended almost a century of conflict between the French and British.
  • The resulting Treaty of Paris reduced the French Company to a trading body without political privileges.

The Battle of Plassey :

1. It was a decisive victory for the British East India Company over the Nawab of Bengal and his French allies on June 23, 1757.

2. The end of the French forces Mir Jafar being crowned as the Nawab of Bengal

3. The battle helped the British East India Company take control of Bengal in 1772.

The battle resulted in:

1. The British gaining political power in Northern India 

The Battle of Buxar :

  • It was fought between the British East India Company and a combined alliance of Indian states on October 22, 1764.

The British forces were led by Major Hector Munro, while the alliance included:

1. Mir Qasim, Nawab of Bengal

2. Shuja-ud-Daula, Nawab of Awadh

3. Shah Alam II, Mughal Emperor

  • The battle took place in Buxar, a fortified town in Bihar, on the banks of the Ganges river. The battle was a result of the misuse of trade privileges by the Nawab of Bengal and the colonialist ambitions of the British East India Company.
  • The British won the battle, with Mir Qasim’s soldiers retreating and the other two surrendering. The battle was a turning point in Indian history, marking the beginning of British rule in India. The Treaty of Allahabad, signed by Shah Alam II on August 12, 1765, ended the war.
  • The battle took place on the banks of the Bhagirathi-Hooghly River, near the small village of Plassey, in north-eastern India.
  • The battle was part of the Third Carnatic War and the worldwide Seven Years’ War (1756-63). T he British East India Company, led by Robert Clive, won because of the defection of Mir Jafar, the commander-in-chief of the Nawab’s army. Clive bribed Mir Jafar, promised to make him Nawab of Bengal, and bought support from his enemies.

 

The treaty forced the defeated Indian rulers to sign it, granting the East India Company diwani rights. This gave the company the right to collect revenue from the territories of Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa on behalf of the Mughal emperor. T he First Battle of Panipat : It was fought on April 21, 1526, between the invading forces of Babur and the Lodi Empire. The battle took place near the small village of Panipat, in the present day Indian state of Haryana. T he Mughal force was outnumbered but prevailed due to the resourcefulness of their commander, Babur. Babur used f ield fortifications and the firepower of gunpowder. It is widely accepted thatBabur’s guns were the decisive factor in the battle because Ibrahim Lodi had no field artillery. The cannons’ sound scared Lodi’s elephants, who crushed Lodi’s soldiers. The battle marked the beginning of the Mughal Empire and the end of the Delhi Sultanate. The Second and Third Battles of Panipat took place in 1556 and 1761.

question: Which of the following was not the outcome of Jallianwalah Bagh massacre? (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Suspension of Gen. Dyer
option_2: Change in Gandhiji’s outlook towards Britishers
option_3: Temporary peace in Punjab
option_4: Renunciation of British titles and positions by many Indians
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Temporary peace in Punjab is not an outcome of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre. The Jallianwala Bagh massacre, also called the Massacre of Amritsar, occurred on April 13, 1919.British troops, led by General Dyer, fired on a crowd of unarmed Indian civilians in an open space called Jallianwala Bagh in Amritsar, Punjab. The massacre was a result of a demonstration against the Rowlatt Act, which was passed in 1919 to extend the British government’s World War I emergency powers to combat subversive activities. Some other outcomes of the massacre include: 1. Newspapers were banned 2. Editors were put behind bars or deported 3. Rabindranath Tagore, who had been knighted by the British, renounced his knighthood 4. The government responded with further brutalities

question: “Inquilab Zindabad” slogan was given by............... (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: Chandra Shekhar Azad
option_2: Subhash Chandra Bose
option_3: Bhagat Singh
option_4: Iqbal
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • “Inquilab Zindabad” is a slogan that means “Long Live Revolution”. It was first introduced by Maulana Hasrat Mohani in 1921. However, Bhagat Singh popularized the slogan through his speeches and writings in the late 1920s.
  • Singh is also credited with making the slogan popular by shouting it during the 1929 bombing of the Central Legislative Assembly.
  • The word “Inquilaab” is of Persian origin and means “revolution, change, turn, or uprising”. It is often used as a political slogan.

question: Who evolved the national consciousness as a formal concept? (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: B.G. Tilak
option_2: Mahatma Gandhi
option_3: Jawaharlal Nehru
option_4: Surendranath Bannerjee
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Surendranath Banerjee is credited with evolving the concept of national consciousness as a formal concept in India. He was a political leader and the founder of the Indian National Association, which was established in 1848 in Kolkata and died in 1925. National consciousness is a shared sense of national identity, which is a shared understanding that a people group shares a common ethnic/linguistic/cultural background. Some factors that have led to the rise of national consciousness in India include: 1. Political unification 2. Impact of Western education 3. Rediscovery of Indian’s glorious past 4. Socio-Religious Reform Movements 5. Growth of Vernacular Literature 6. Press and Newspaper 7. Economic Exploitation of British 8. Racial Antagonism

question: “Red Shirts” movement aimed at.............. (UPSC Prelims 1979)
option_1: To throw out Britishers from India
option_2: To promote Communist organizational activities
option_3: To promote trade union activities
option_4: All of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

question: Swadeshi movement started during............... (UPSC Prelims 1979)

option_2: Non Cooperation Movement
option_3: Civil Disobedience Movement
option_4: None of the above

Explanation : (A)

  • The Swadeshi Movement began in India on August 7, 1905, during the Anti-Bengal Partition agitation. The movement was a reaction to the partition of Bengal, which was announced in July 1905 and came into effect in October 1905.
  • The Swadeshi movement was a six-year (1905–1911) anti-partition movement.

The movement’s main principles include:

1. Swadeshi: Using products and services from one’s own country

2. Boycott: Refraining from using British goods

3. Self-reliance: Aiming for economic self-reliance and independence from British rule

4. Nationalism: Contributing to the development of Indian nationalism

  • The movement began in 1905 in response to the British government’s decision to partition Bengal.

The movement’s main features include:

1. Boycotting foreign goods

2. Promoting indigenous industries

3. Mass mobilization

4. Burning British-made goods

  • The Swadeshi movement is now known as the “Make in India” campaign.

The Non-Cooperation Movement :

  • It was a peaceful protest against the British government in India that lasted from 1920 to 1922. The movement was a political campaign led by Mahatma Gandhi to persuade the British to grant self-governance to India. The movement’s main goal was to achieve “Poorna swaraj” through peaceful means.

The movement was triggered by many reasons, including:

  • The Jallianwala Bagh massacre On April 13, 1919, a large crowd of unarmed men, women, and children were shot at with machine guns and rifles by General Dyer.

The Government of India Act of 1919 :

  • This act curtailed the right to vote and gave Indians little say in government decisions.

Resentment at the British after the war :

  • Indians felt betrayed by the British after they provided extensive support of manpower and resources during the First World War.

The movement consisted of Indians:

1. Resigning their titles

2. Boycotting government educational institutions, the courts, government service, foreign goods, and elections

3. Eventually, refusing to pay taxes

  • The British government responded with severe repression, arresting thousands of protesters and imposing harsh punishments. This led to further resentment and fueled the demand for independence.

The Civil Disobedience Movement (CDM) :

  • It was a major mass movement launched in 1930 by Mahatma Gandhi.

The CDM’s demands included:

 1. Releasing political prisoners

2. Reducing the rupee-sterling exchange ratio

3. Reducing agricultural tax by 50%

4. Eliminating the government’s monopoly on salt

6. Reducing the rupee-sterling exchange ratio Reducing agricultural tax by 50%

  • The CDM was withdrawn in 1931 when Gandhi signed the “Gandhi-Irwin” pact.
  • Civil disobedience is a nonviolent action where an individual refuses to obey a law for moral or philosophical reasons. It can be active or passive, direct or indirect. The purpose of civil disobedience is usually to force concessions from the government or occupying power.

Some examples of civil disobedience include:

1. The Boston Tea Party

2. Mahatma Gandhi’s Salt March

3. Suffragists’ illegal voting

4. Whites-only lunch counter sit-ins

5. Youth climate movement school walkouts

Civil disobedience is also known as passive resistance. It has been a major tactic and philosophy of many social movements, including:

1. Nationalist movements in Africa and India

2. The American civil rights movement

3. Labor movements

4. Anti-war movements

question: The year 1919 is associated with............. (UPSC Prelims 1980)
option_1: Dandi March by Mahatma Gandhi
option_2: Jallianwala Bagh Tragedy
option_3: Chauri Chaura Incident
option_4: Partition of Bengal
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

The year 1919 is associated with many events, including:

The Rowlatt Act :

  • In February 1919, the Imperial Legislative Council of British India passed the Rowlatt Act, which extended the Defence of India Act of 1915. The act allowed the trial of political cases without juries and the internment of suspects without trial.

The Rowlatt Satyagraha :

  • On April 6, 1919, Mahatma Gandhi began a non-violent protest against the Rowlatt Act, which he called the Rowlatt Satyagraha. The protest included a nationwide hartal, where people were asked to stop going to work and hold meetings against the act.

The Jallianwala Bagh Massacre :

  • The Rowlatt Act led to a chain of events that culminated in the Jallianwala Bagh massacre. On Baisakhi, a day of celebration and peaceful protest, General Dyer ordered fire on a crowd gathered in Jallianwala Bagh without warning.

Some other outcomes of the massacre include:

1. Newspapers were banned
2. Editors were put behind bars or deported
3. Rabindranath Tagore, who had been knighted by the British, renounced his knighthood
4. The government responded with further brutalities.

Dandi March:

  • Mahatma Gandhi started the Dandi March on March 12, 1930. The march lasted until April 6, 1930.
  • The Dandi March, also known as the Salt March and the Dandi Satyagraha, was a nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly. The march was a direct action campaign of tax resistance and protest against injustice.
  • The march began at Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad and ended in Dandi, a coastal town in Gujarat. The march was nearly 385 km long and Gandhi was accompanied by 80 satyagrahis.
  • Gandhi inaugurated the Civil Disobedience Movement by picking up a handful of salt in Dandi. He continued his satyagraha against the salt tax for the next two months, encouraging other Indians to break the salt laws.

The Chauri Chaura incident:

  • It occurred on February 4, 1922, when police in the town of Chauri Chaura, India. The protesters were participating in the Non-cooperation movement, which was led by Mahatma Gandhi. The clash resulted in the deaths of about 22 policemen and 3 civilians.
  • The incident led to Mahatma Gandhi calling off the Non-Cooperation Movement, which lasted from 1920-1922. 225 people were arrested, and 6 died in police custody. In July 1923, 19 people were executed after a trial, and 113 were sentenced to varying years of imprisonment.

The Partition of Bengal:

  • It was a territorial reorganization of the Bengal Presidency that took place on October 16, 1905. The British Raj implemented the partition, which separated the largely Hindu western areas from the largely Muslim eastern areas.
  • The partition divided the province into West Bengal and East Bengal. The Muslims supported the partition because they would have their own province, but the Hindus opposed it.
  • The partition led to a nationalist movement known as the Swadeshi Movement. The movement advocated boycotting British goods and promoting Indian-made products to protest against the partition and assert Indian self-reliance.
  • The partition also brought the province to the brink of open rebellion. The British recognized that Bengal was too large for a single province and determined that it needed reorganization and division.

question: Which of the following was the main feature of the policy of Dual Government of British rulers in India? (UPSC Prelims 1980)

T he Company was responsible for military power and the right to collect and use the revenue of Bengal. T he Company directly collected its revenues through the right to nominate the Deputy Subahdar The Company controlled the Nizamat of the police and judicial powers.T he dual system of government was abolished by Warren Hastings in 1772 and Bengal was brought under direct control of the British.

question: The DYARCHY as introduced by the Government of India Act, 1919 postulated which of the following? (UPSC Prelims 1980)

It was a constitutional reform that introduced democratic principles to the executive branch of the British administration of India. Dyarchy meant: 1. Dividing powers between the central and provincial governments 2. Dividing the executive department between elected ministers and the members of the Governor’s Executive Council 3. Separating the judiciary from the executive Dyarchy also meant dividing subjects delegated to the provinces into two categories: 1. “Reserved” subjects, which included finance, irrigation, law and order, and land revenue 2. “Transferred” subjects, which included local government, health, education, and excise Dyarchy was a breakthrough in British Indian government. It led to India’sfull provincial autonomy in 1935 and independence in 1947.

question: Who was the Viceroy when Attlee declared India’s Independence? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Lord Wavell
option_2: Lord Mountbatten
option_3: Lord William Bentinck
option_4: Lord Cornwallis
solution_text: Explanation : (B) Lord Louis Mountbatten was the Viceroy of India when British Prime Minister Clement Attlee declared India’s independence on August 15, 1947. Mountbatten was appointed Viceroy in March 1947, replacing Lord Wavell. In June 1947, Mountbatten announced that Britain’s departure date would be moved up to August 15, 1947. T he Mountbatten Plan, also known as the 3 June Plan, was the last plan for India’s independence. The plan included provisions for partitioning British India into two dominions, India and Pakistan.

question:
What is the correct order of happenings of the following three events in the British rule in India? (UPSC Prelims 1981)

1. Rowlatt Act

2. Hunter Report

3. Jallianwalla Bagh Tragedy

Select the correct answer from the codes given below:
option_1: 1, 3, 2
option_2: 2, 1, 3
option_3: 3, 2, 1
option_4: 2, 3, 1
solution_text: Explanation : (A) T he Rowlatt Act, officially known as the Anarchical and Revolutionary Crimes Act of 1919, was passed by the British government in March 1919. T he act gave the British government the power to:1. 2. 3. 4. 5. Arrest anyone suspected of terrorist activities Detain people arrested for up to two years without trial Search places without a warrant Place severe restrictions on the freedom of the press T he purpose of the Act was to curb the growing nationalist upsurge in the country. Mahatma Gandhi called upon the people to perform satyagraha against the act. T he Rowlatt Act was popularly known as the “Black Act” in the Indian freedom movement during the British period. T he Rowlatt Act also restricted civil liberties, such as freedom of speech and assembly. This led to nationwide unrest. Gandhi initiated Satyagraha to protest against the Rowlatt Act. However, Gandhi was overwhelmed by the atmosphere of total violence and withdrew the movement on April 18, 1919. In 1922, after the massacre and the report of the Oppressive Laws Committee, the Act got repealed.T he Jallianwala Bagh massacre :It is also called the Massacre of Amritsar, occurred on April 13, 1919. British troops, led by General Dyer, fired on a crowd of unarmed Indian civilians in an open space called Jallianwala Bagh in Amritsar, Punjab. T he massacre was a result of a demonstration against the Rowlatt Act, which was passed in 1919 to extend the British government’s World War I emergency powers to combat subversive activities. Some other outcomes of the massacre include: 1. 2. 3. 4. Newspapers were banned Editors were put behind bars or deported Rabindranath Tagore, who had been knighted by the British, renounced his knighthood T he government responded with further brutalitiesThe Hunter Commission Report of 1919 : It concluded that the gathering in Jallianwala Bagh was not a conspiracy to overthrow British rule in Punjab. The commission also found that the declaration of martial law in Punjab was justified. However, the commission concluded that Dyer’s firing at the mob was justified, except that he should have given a warning first and shortened the duration of the firing. The commission also concluded that the duration of firing (10 minutes), as ordered by Dyer, was a grave error. The Hunter Commission was appointed by Edwin Montagu, the Secretary of State for India. The commission’s official name was the Disorders Inquiry Committee. The commission was chaired by Sir William Hunter, an Indian Civil Service officer and member of the Viceroy’s Executive Council.

question: Who said these words at the time of Quit India Movement-“Do or die”? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Motilal Nehru
option_2: Mahatma Gandhi
option_3: Sardar Patel
option_4: Subhash Chandra Bose
solution_text: Explanation : (B) Mahatma Gandhi said the words “Do or Die” during the launch of the Quit India Movement in 1942. The speech took place at the Gowalia Tank Maidan, now known as the August Kranti Maidan, in Mumbai. The slogan is associated with the beginning of the Quit India Movement, which also goes by the names August Movement and August Kranti Movement. The Quit India Movement was a Gandhi led effort to uproot British imperialism. The speech was a final push to make the British leave. Gandhi called for a voluntary British withdrawal from India, taking advantage of the failure of the Cripps Mission, the Japanese advances in South-East Asia, and the general frustration with the British in India.

question: Under whose leadership, the Indian National Army was formed? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Mahatma Gandhi
option_2: Subhash Chandra Bose
option_3: Jawaharlal Nehru
option_4: Gopal Krishna Gokhale
solution_text: Explanation : (B) The Indian National Army (INA) was formed in 1942 with the assistance of the Japanese during World War II. It was formed by Subhash Chandra Bose, an Indian nationalist leader, with the help of Rash Behari Bose. The INA is also known as the Azad Hind Fauj. In 1941, Bose escaped India and went to Germany to work for India’s independence. In 1943, he came to Singapore to lead the Indian Independence League and rebuild the INA. The INA’s goal was to fight against the British in Southeast Asia alongside the Axis powers.

question: The Indian National Movement refers to the.......... (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Movement started by Subhash Chandra Bose through INA.
option_2: Struggle by the Indians to gain freedom from British colonial rule in India.
option_3: Struggle by Indians to gain dominion status under British rule.
option_4: Struggle by Indians to stop British trade in India.
solution_text: Explanation : (B) The Indian National Movement was a series of mass movements that took place from 1857 to 1947. The movements were a result of the rise of Indian nationalism and consciousness. They were led by various political parties and organizations and took many forms, including non-cooperation, civil disobedience, and armed protests. The movements lasted for almost a century and ended with India’s independence from British rule on August 15, 1947. The Indian National Movement helped to unite disparate people and social groupsinto one nation. Awareness began to emerge with the growth of English education in a few important urban areas, including Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay, in the late 19th century. Bal Gangadhar Tilak is considered the Father of Indian National Movement. He was a social reformer, freedom fighter, national leader, and a scholar of Indian history, sanskrit, hinduism, mathematics and astronomy.

question: Why did Gandhiji stop the Non- Cooperation Movement? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Because of Gandhi Irwin Pact
option_2: Because the mob turned violent
option_3: Because he was ordered to do so by the Britishers
option_4: Because he did not like to continue the movement
solution_text: Explanation : (B) Mahatma Gandhi called off the Non Cooperation Movement in 1922 after a protest turned violent and killed several policemen. The incident occurred on February 5, 1922, when a mob clashed with police and set fire to a police station in Chauri Chaura, Uttar Pradesh. Gandhiji, who was against violence, believed that the people were not yet ready for a mass struggle. He felt that satyagrahis needed to be properly trained for non violent demonstrations. The Non-Cooperation Movement was a mass movement that shook the British government and established the popularity of the Congress Party. The movement also showcased communal harmony with participation from both Hindus and Muslims.

question: Purna Swaraj Day was observed on........... (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: 26th November, 1947
option_2: 26th October, 1949
option_3: 26th January, 1950
option_4: 26th January, 1930
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (D)

  • Purna Swaraj Day was observed on January 26, 1930. The resolution called for "complete freedom from the British". However, Prime Minister Nehru later interpreted the resolution as allowing India to remain in the British Commonwealth.
  • The Congress working committee decided to observe January 26, 1930 as "Poorna Swarajya Day" on January 2, 1930 at the last Congress session presided over by Jawaharlal Nehru.

question: Which of the following represents the integration of Hindus and Muslims for a common cause? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Khilafat Movement
option_2: Quit India Movement
option_3: Civil Disobedience Movement
option_4: None of the above
solution_text: Explanation : (A) The Khilafat Movement : It was a political campaign that took place from 1919–1924.It was a protest by Indian Muslims against British policies towards Turkey and the Ottoman Empire after World War I. The movement’s goal was to pressure the British government to keep the Ottoman Sultan as Caliph of Islam after the Ottoman Empire’s breakup. The movement also aimed to unite the Muslim community in India behind the broader Indian nationalist movement. It sought to address Turkey’s grievances and promote Hindu-Muslim unity. The movement was abruptly called off on February 12, 1922, at Gandhiji’s insistence, following the news of the Chauri Chaura incident.

question: Which of the following periods can be considered as the era of mass revolution? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: 1856 1885 AD
option_2: 1757-1857 AD
option_3: 1920-1947 AD
option_4: 1901-1919 AD
solution_text: Explanation : (C) The period from 1920 to 1947 can be considered as the era of mass revolution. The Second Industrial Revolution, also known as the Technological Revolution, was a phase of rapid scientific discovery, standardisation, mass production, and industrialization from the late 19th century into the early 20th century. The Age of Revolutions includes the American Revolution, the French Revolution, the Irish Rebellion of 1798, the Haitian Revolution, the revolt of slaves in Latin America, and of course the wave of revolutions across Europe in 1848 among others. Mahatma Gandhi’s mass movements are focused on fighting against colonial rule while following non-violent principles. The period from 1919 to 1948 is known as the Gandhian era in Indian history because Gandhi dominated the Indian National Congress during this time. Some of Gandhi’s major movements include: 1. Champaran Movement: A nonviolent civil disobedience campaign in 1917 in the Champaran district of Bihar 2. Kheda Movement: In 1918 3. Khilafat Movement: In 1920, a worldwide protest was organized to combat the status of the Caliph 4. Non-cooperation Movement: In 1920 5. Civil Disobedience Movement: In 1930 6. Dandi March: Also known as the “Salt movement or Dandi Satyagraha” in 1930, Gandhi marched from Sabarmati Ashram to the coastal village of Dandi to protest the high salt tax 7. Quit India Movement: In 1942, Gandhi launched a mass civil disobedience movement that forced the British to leave India

question: Whom did Gandhiji consider his political Guru? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Vinoba Bhave
option_2: B. G. Tilak
option_3: Gopal Krishna Gokhale
option_4: Dadabhai Naoroji
solution_text: Explanation : (C) Mahatma Gandhi considered Gopal Krishna Gokhale to be his political guru. Gokhale was a senior leader of the Indian National Congress and the founder of the Servants of India Society. Gokhale guided Gandhi after he returned from South Africa with his knowledge of Indian issues. Gokhale’s advice led Gandhi to travel throughout India’s rural hinterland to understand the situation of the people. Gokhale also encouraged Gandhi to travel in a third-class railway compartment to understand India from a different perspective. Gokhale was a member of the Bombay Legislative Council from 1899 to 1902 and worked at the Imperial Legislative Council from 1902 until his death in 1915. At the Imperial legislature, Gokhale played a key role in framing the Morley-Minto reforms of 1909.

question: Who among the following were associated with the birth of Swarajya Party? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: C. R. Das and Motilal Nehru
option_2: C. R. Das and Sardar Patel
option_3: Motilal Nehru and Rajendra Prasad
option_4: None of the above
solution_text: Explanation : (A) Motilal Nehru and Chittaranjan Das were the founders of the Swaraj Party, an Indian political party established in late 1922–early 1923. Both were prominent lawyers and members of the Indian National Congress.After the noncooperation movement, they gave up their professions and homes. The Swaraj Party was formed on January 1, 1923 to fight British colonialism and demonstrate that councils were not truly democratic.

question: The Indian patriot, who died in jail due to hunger strike, was............. (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: S. C. Bose
option_2: Bhagat Singh
option_3: Jatin Das
option_4: Bipin Chandra Pal
solution_text: Explanation : (C) Jatindra Nath Das, also known as Jatin Das, was an Indian independence activist and revolutionary who died in jail after a 63 day hunger strike. Das was arrested by the British on June 14, 1929, in connection with the Lahore Conspiracy Case. He died on September 13, 1929, after fasting to protect political prisoners from injustice. Das’s determination and commitment drew attention to the plight of political prisoners and inspired thousands to stand up against British rule.

question: Who among the following was responsible for the revival of Hinduism in the 19th century? (UPSC Prelims 1981)
option_1: Swami Dayanand
option_2: Swami Vivekanand
option_3: Guru Shankaracharya
option_4: Raja Rammohan Roy
solution_text: Explanation : (B) Swami Vivekananda is widely regarded as the key figure in the revival of Hinduism in the 19th century. Vivekananda was a disciple of Sri Ramakrishna, and a major force in contemporary Hindu reform movements. He was an influential philosopher and social reformer in India, and the most successful missionaries of Vedanta to the Western world. Vivekananda’s work reconciled the devotional path of his guru with the path of knowledge. He also contributed to the concept of nationalism in colonial India. The Hindu revival and reform movements of the 19th and early 20th centuries were closely linked with the growth of Indian nationalism and the struggle for independence.

question: The personality who is not connected with 1857 mutiny is............. (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Bhagat Singh
option_2: Lakshmibai
option_3: Tantia Tope
option_4: Nana Saheb
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (A)

  • Bhagat Singh was not connected with the Revolt of 1857. He was a revolutionary freedom fighter who played a prominent role in India’s independence movement in the 20th century, particularly during the 1920s. Bhagat Singh was part of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA) and is best remembered for his fearless acts against British rule, including the bombing of the Central Legislative Assembly in 1929 and the killing of British officer John Saunders. He was executed in 1931, long after the 1857 uprising.
  • In contrast, the other personalities listed were directly involved in the Revolt of 1857, also known as the First War of Indian Independence. 
  • Rani Lakshmibai, the Queen of Jhansi, was one of the most prominent leaders of the revolt who fought valiantly against the British to defend her kingdom. 
  • Tantia Tope was a close associate of Nana Saheb and a brilliant military leader who led several battles against the British during the rebellion. 
  • Nana Saheb, the adopted son of Peshwa Baji Rao II, led the uprising in Kanpur (Cawnpore) and played a key role in organizing Indian forces against British rule.
  • Therefore, among the given options, Bhagat Singh stands out as the personality not connected with the 1857 Mutiny, since he belonged to a later generation of freedom fighters.

question: Who among the following founded Ramakrishna Mission? (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Swami Dayanand Saraswati
option_2: Raja Rammohan Roy

option_4: None of these

Vivekananda was the chief disciple of Sri Ramakrishna, an Indian Hindu spiritual guru and mystic.The Ramakrishna Mission is a philanthropic organization that works in healthcare, disaster relief, rural management, tribal welfare, elementary and higher education, and culture. The mission also propagates the Hindu philosophy of Vedanta–Advaita Vedanta and four yogic ideals. The Ramakrishna Mission was founded at the monastery of Belur Math on the Ganges River near Calcutta (now Kolkata). The mission’s ideals are self-perfection and service.

question: Dandi March was organised by Gandhiji to............ (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Break the salt laws
option_2: Protest against atrocities on Harijans
option_3: Oppose Simon Commission
option_4: Ask for Purna Swaraj
solution_text: Explanation : (A) Dandi March, also known as the Salt March and the Salt Satyagraha, was a nonviolent civil disobedience movement led by Mahatma Gandhi from March 12, 1930 to April 6, 1930. The march was a direct action campaign of tax resistance and nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly. Gandhi and other nationalists believed that it was sinful to tax salt because it is such an essential item of food. The march was a 24-day march from Gandhi’s Sabarmati Ashram to the coastal town of Dandi to produce salt from the sea and defy the salt law. The march was a highly visible demonstration against the increasingly repressive salt tax. The march was a major nonviolent protest action in India directed against the British government’s tax on salt, which greatly affected the poorest Indians. Mahatma Gandhi’s Harijan campaign is a significant movement : It aims to address social discrimination and untouchability in India. In 1932, Gandhi established the Harijan Sevak Sangh organization to uplift the Harijans (Depressed Class or Dalits) and end untouchability. Gandhi’s campaign is considered as vital as winning political freedom. In his campaign, Gandhi referred to the oppressed class as “Harijans” or “sons of God”. He also called the untouchables “Harijans” or “Children of God” and worked long for their liberation. The Simon Commission : It is also known as the Indian Statutory Commission, was a group of seven British Parliament members sent to India in 1928 to study potential constitutional reform. The commission was chaired by Sir John Simon, and the report it published in 1930 is known as the Simon Report. The Simon Commission was boycotted by Indians because it had no Indian representatives. The commission’s all white membership was seen as an insult to Indians, who believed that a few British people should not be able to determine their destiny. The Simon Commission accepted the idea of federalism and sought to maintain direct contact between the British crown and Indian states. The Simon Report was important in the constitutional discussions that led to the Government of India Act of 1935.

question: Who among the following was not a moderate? (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Mahatma Gandhi
option_2: W. C. Bannerjee
option_3: G. K. Gokhale
option_4: B. G. Tilak
solution_text: Explanation : (D) Bal Gangadhar Tilak (1856-1920) was not a moderate. He was an extremist leader who opposed moderate ways of thinking and had a more radical and aggressive stance against British control. Tilak was one of the first advocates of swaraj, or self-rule, and his slogan was “Swaraj is my birthright & I shall have it”. In 1907, Congress was divided into groups of extremists and moderates. Moderates wanted to resolve government issues through deliberations whereas Extremists believed in strikes, agitation, and boycott to force their demands.

question: Civil Disobedience Movement was started in India in 1930 for............ (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Home rule
option_2: Purna Swaraj
option_3: Non cooperation with British government
option_4: Hindu-Muslim unity
solution_text:
EXPLANATION : (B)

  • The Civil Disobedience Movement, launched by Mahatma Gandhi in 1930, was aimed at achieving Purna Swaraj, or complete independence from British rule. The movement began with the historic Dandi March (Salt Satyagraha), where Gandhi marched from Sabarmati Ashram to Dandi to protest the British salt tax. The movement encouraged Indians to break unjust laws peacefully, refuse to pay taxes, boycott British goods, and promote self-reliance. It marked a major shift in India’s freedom struggle, as it demanded total independence rather than limited reforms.

Home Rule Movement :

  • It refers to the Home Rule Movement started in 1916 by Bal Gangadhar Tilak and Annie Besant. It sought self-government or dominion status within the British Empire, similar to the status enjoyed by colonies like Canada and Australia. While it aroused political awareness among Indians, it did not demand complete freedom from British rule, as the Civil Disobedience Movement later did.

Non-cooperation with British government :

  • It refers to the Non-Cooperation Movement of 1920–1922, also led by Gandhi. It aimed to resist British rule through peaceful non-cooperation—by boycotting schools, offices, courts, and foreign goods. However, it was called off after the Chauri Chaura incident in 1922 when protestors turned violent. This movement laid the foundation for later struggles like Civil Disobedience but was distinct in purpose and time.

Hindu-Muslim unity :

  • It was a significant objective during the Khilafat and Non-Cooperation Movements, as Gandhi sought to unite the two communities in a joint struggle against British rule. However, it was not the main aim of the Civil Disobedience Movement, which focused on complete independence.
  • In conclusion, while Home Rule, Non-Cooperation, and Hindu-Muslim unity were important phases and ideals in India’s freedom struggle, the Civil Disobedience Movement of 1930 was specifically launched for the goal of Purna Swaraj (complete independence) — making option (b) the correct answer.

question: Non-Cooperation Movement was called off by Gandhiji because............ (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Of Chauri Chaura incident
option_2: Government accepted the demands of Indian leaders
option_3: Of repressive measures adopted by the government
option_4: None of these
solution_text: Explanation : (A) In February 1922, Mahatma Gandhi called off the Non-Cooperation Movement because he was against violence. The movement was intended to be non-violent, but it turned violent after a mob killed several policemen at Chauri Chaura in the United Provinces. Gandhi felt that the people were not ready for a mass struggle, and that satyagrahis needed to be properly trained for non violent demonstrations. The Non-Cooperation Movement was launched in 1920 with the aim of obtaining self-governance and ultimately getting the British colonial authorities to grant full independence to India.

question: Raja Rammohan Roy was supporter of............... (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Sati
option_2: Widow re-marriage
option_3: Child marriage
option_4: Learning of Sanskrit
solution_text: Explanation : (B) Raja Ram Mohan Roy was a supporter of widow remarriage. Roy was an Indian social reformer who campaigned for women’s rights, including the right for widows to remarry. He also opposed child marriage and polygamy. Roy’s efforts led to the abolition of Sati in 1829. Sati is the practice of burning widows alive. In 1856, the Hindu Widows’ Remarriage Act was enacted, legalizing the remarriageof Hindu widows across all jurisdictions. Roy was also known for his pioneering thought and action on the emancipation of women. He campaigned against the caste system, untouchability, superstitions, and use of intoxicants.

question: Doctrine of Lapse was adopted as a measure to annex Indian states by............. (UPSC Prelims 1982)
option_1: Lord Cornwallis
option_2: Lord Clive
option_3: Lord Dalhousie
option_4: Lord Wellesley
solution_text: Explanation : (C) The Doctrine of Lapse was a policy used by the East India Company to annex princely states in the Indian subcontinent. The policy was devised by Lord Dalhousie, the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856, to deal with questions of succession to Hindu Indian states. The policy was applied until 1858, when the British Raj took over rule from the East India Company. The policy was based on the British belief that they had a moral and legal obligation to modernize and stabilize Indian states. The policy stated that any princely state or territory under the British East India Company would automatically be annexed if the ruler died without a male heir. Satara was the first state annexed under the doctrine of lapse in 1848. The policy was a main political cause for the great revolt of 1857. In 1857, a group of Indian rulers formed a secret society called the “Sepoy Mutiny” to overthrow the East India Company. This uprising was unsuccessful, but it did lead to the end of the doctrine of lapse in 1859.

question: Some persons who were close associates of Gandhiji died recently. They were............. (UPSC Prelims 1983)
option_1: Anandmayi Ma, Pyarelal, Vinoba Bhave
option_2: Mira Behn, J.P. Narayan, Lord Mountbatten. Manibhai Desai

question: Who represented India at the Chicago Conference of World Religions in 1893? (UPSC Prelims 1983)
option_1: Swami Vivekananda
option_2: Swami Dayananda
option_3: Swami Abhedananda
option_4: Ramakrishna Paramhansa
solution_text: Explanation : (A) Swami Vivekananda represented India and Hinduism at the first World’s Parliament of Religions in Chicago in 1893. The Parliament was held from September 11 27, 1893, and was the first formal gathering of representatives from different spiritual traditions. Vivekananda was a Hindu monk who introduced Hinduism at the opening session of the Parliament on September 11, 1893. His speech introduced Hinduism to America and called for religious tolerance and an end to fanaticism. He also emphasized the importance of religious tolerance, universal acceptance, and the idea that all religions lead to the same truth. On September 20, 1893, Vivekananda also delivered a lecture titled “Religion not the crying need of India”. In this lecture, he criticized Christian missionaries for ignoring the needs of starving people in India.

question: The capital of India was shifted from Calcutta to Delhi in the year.............. (UPSC Prelims 1983)
option_1: 1905
option_2: 1911
option_3: 1912
option_4: 1916
solution_text: Explanation : (B) The British Empire proclaimed the shifting of the capital of India from Calcutta toDelhi on December 12, 1911. The actual transfer of capital took place in 1912. The British government believed that ruling India from Delhi was easier and more convenient than from Calcutta. Delhi’s location in the center of northern India and its links with the Mughal empire and Hindu “sacred legends” were also factors. Construction of the new capital began in 1912 at a site about 3 miles (5 km) south of the Delhi city center. The new capital was formally dedicated in 1931.

question: The theory of economic drain from India to England was propounded by.............. (UPSC Prelims 1983)
option_1: Dadabhai Naoroji
option_2: R. C. Dutt
option_3: G. Tilak
option_4: L.K Jha
solution_text: Explanation : (A) Dadabhai Naoroji propounded the “Drain Theory” in 1867. The theory is also known as the “economic imperialism” theory. The theory states that the British exploited India’s resources in two ways: 1. Home charges: Interest paid to England by Indians for “developing” India 2. Unrequited export: British workers in India sent their savings to England The theory is a landmark in the Indian independence movement. It incorporated the nationalist critique of colonialism, as the drain deprived India of the productive capital its agriculture and industries needed. Naoroji was a founding member of the Indian National Congress and was elected president three times. He was also the first Asian to be a British MP.

question: Indian National Congress was founded by............... (UPSC Prelims 1983)
option_1: W. C. Bannerjee
option_2: A. O. Hume
option_3: Mahatma Gandhi
option_4: Annie Besant
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Indian National Congress (INC) was founded on December 28, 1885 by Allan Octavian Hume, Surendranath Banerjee, and Womesh Chunder Bonnerjee. The INC’s first session was held in Bombay from December 28–31, 1885. The INC was India’s first political national movement. Its initial goal was to involve more Indians in the country’s governance. Later, its goal changed to complete independence. After independence, the INC became a major political party in India.

question: Who can be called the father of local self- government in India? (UPSC Prelims 1983)
option_1: Lord Ripon
option_2: Lord Minto
option_3: Lord Curzon
option_4: Lord Dullerin
solution_text: Explanation : (A) Lord Ripon : He is known as the “Father of Local Self Government” in India. In 1882, the then Viceroy of India, Lord Ripon, passed a resolution that led to democratic forms of municipal governance in India. He was a staunch Liberal democrat with faith in self government. Ripon believed that self government is the highest and noblest principles of politics. Therefore, Ripon helped the growth of local bodies like the Municipal Committees in towns and the local boards in talukas and villages. The powers of municipalities were increased. Lord Ripon’s Resolution of Local Bodies included: 1. Elections: Non-officials were elected to urban and rural local bodies. Rent-payers could participate in the election. 2. Positions: Non-officials could hold the position of chairman in the local bodies.Local self-government is a democratic form of governance that empowers local communities and authorities to make decisions on matters that directly affect their areas.

question: The first great experiment of Gandhiji in ‘Satyagraha’ took place in............ (UPSC Prelims 1983)
option_1: Dandi
option_2: Champaran
option_3: Ahmedabad
option_4: Bardoli
solution_text: Explanation : (B) Mahatma Gandhi’s first great experiment in Satyagraha took place in Champaran, Bihar in 1917. The Champaran Satyagraha was a farmers’ uprising during the British colonial era in 1917. It’s considered a historically important rebellion in the Indian independence movement. In 1917, Gandhi was persuaded by Rajkumar Shukla, an indigo cultivator, to go to Champaran to investigate the conditions of the farmers there. He adopted non violent Satyagraha as a mass movement to oppose the coercive acts against farmers. Satyagraha, or “holding firmly to truth”, or “truth force”, is a particular form of nonviolent resistance or civil resistance. The Dandi March : It is also known as the Salt March, was a nonviolent civil disobedience campaign led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi from March 12, 1930 to April 6, 1930. The march was a protest against the British salt monopoly, which was established by the 1882 Salt Act. The act gave the British a monopoly on the collection and manufacture of salt, and levied a tax on it. Gandhi and other nationalists believed that taxing salt was sinful because it is a basic food item. The march was a centerpiece of the 1930 Salt Satyagraha, which was a protest against the increasingly repressive salt tax. The march began with a core group of followers, and hundreds more joinedthem along the way. On April 5, the group reached Dandi after a 240-mile (385 km) journey. Gandhi was arrested in early May after informing the British governor of India of his intention to march on the Dharasana saltworks. News of Gandhi’s imprisonment led tens of thousands more Indians to join the satyagraha. The Dandi March and Gandhi’s satyagraha teachings had a significant influence on American activists like Martin Luther King Jr. and James Bevel during the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. The Bardoli Satyagraha : It was a farmers’ movement and nationalist movement in India that began on June 12, 1928. The movement was led by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and protested against the British colonial government’s oppressive land revenue policies. The movement demanded the repeal of the 22% tax increase levied by the Bombay Presidency. The Bardoli Taluk in modern-day Gujarat was hit by floods and famines in 1925, which affected the crop yield and the farmers financially. Despite petitions and appeals from civic groups and farmers, the government decided to go ahead with tax collection. The peasants adopted a resolution to not pay the assessment until an inquiry was set up. The government acted aggressively and issued notices to pay the assessment or suffer loss of property or forfeiture of land. The government confiscated a large chunk of land. The government set up the Maxwell Broomfield commission, in the fear that things would go out of hand by the Bardoli Satyagraha. The revenue was reduced to around 6.03% and the peasants came to return the lands which were confiscated from them. The movement was a turning point in the Indian nationalist fight. However, the movement also had some criticisms: 1. It mostly ignored the plight of impoverished farmers. 2. It did not bring up the issue of Hali Pratha (a kind of bonded labor system). 3. The peasants’ fundamental problems were not addressed.

question: Which of the following was mainly responsible for the transfer of power by the British to India on August 15, 1947? (UPSC Prelims 1983)

option_2: Attlee Declaration

solution_text: Explanation : (D) Lord Mountbatten, the last viceroy of British India, was mainly responsible for the transfer of power to India on August 15, 1947. Mountbatten chose August 15, 1947 because it was the day in 1945 that the Japanese Army surrendered in World War II. The British Parliament ratified the Mountbatten Plan on July 18, 1947, for the Independence of India Act, which was implemented on August 15, 1947. The British partitioned India in 1947 due to a complex interplay of factors, including: 1. Rising communal tensions in the 1930s2. Political choices made by elites at both national and provincial levels 3. The impact of the Second World War 4. The widespread breakdown of law and order following the ‘Great Calcutta Killing’ in 1946 The Cabinet Mission Plan : It was a statement made in 1946 by the British Prime Minister Clement Attlee. The plan proposed a three-tier administrative structure for British India. The plan also aimed to: 1. Strengthen India’s unity 2. Help India achieve independence 3. Avoid partition The Cabinet Mission Plan proposed the formation of a Union of India, comprising both the British India and the Princely States. The Union would remain in charge of only foreign affairs, defense, and communications. The remaining powers would be vested in the provinces. The Cabinet Mission Plan raised the issue of whether independence was to result in a united India or one divided into Hindu and Muslim areas. The Congress opposed the creation of Pakistan as the Cabinet Mission Plan did not guarantee a separate sovereign state for Muslims. Atlee Declaration : On February 20, 1947, British Prime Minister Clement Attlee announced that the British government would grant full self-government to British India by June 30, 1948. The announcement also stated that the future of the Princely States would be decided after the date of final transfer is decided. Attlee’s announcement also granted freedom to the Indian princely states to either join the Dominion of India or Dominion of Pakistan or to remain independent. • The Indian Independence Act was passed in 1947, creating two new independent dominions: 1. India and 2. Pakistan. Pakistan was later split into Pakistan and East Pakistan, which is now Bangladesh. The Simon Commission : It was a group of seven British Members of Parliament that was appointed in 1927 to study the Government of India Act of 1919. The commission’s purpose was to examine the act and recommend improvements to the system. The commission’s plan was to abolish diarchy, which would have extended provincial autonomy by establishing representative government. However, the plan would have allowed British governors to retain most of their emergency powers. The Simon Commission was strongly opposed by national leaders and freedom fighters because the British administration did not include any Indians in the commission. The commission led to the Government of India Act of 1935, which served as the basis for many parts of the current Indian Constitution.

question:
Write the correct chronological order of the following annexations by the Britishers............... (UPSC Prelims 1984)

1. Oudh

2. Punjab

3. Upper Burma

Select the correct answer from the codes given below:
option_1: 3 2 1
option_2: 1 2 3
option_3: 1 3 2
option_4: 2 1 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The British annexed the Punjab on March 29, 1849, following the Second Anglo-Sikh War. The war lasted from 1848–1849 and involved the British-Indian forces fightingthe Sikh Empire. The East India Company defeated the Sikh Empire at the Battle of Gujarat on February 21, 1849, which ended the war. By April 2, 1849, the entire Punjab was incorporated into the British Raj.
  • The Punjab was one of the last areas of the Indian subcontinent to fall under British control. The British were impressed by the f ighting qualities of the Khalsa and began to recruit Sikhs into their military.
  • The British annexed Oudh on February 7, 1856, under the terms of the Doctrine of Lapse. The Doctrine of Lapse allowed the British to annex Indian kingdoms if the ruler died without a male heir.
  • The annexation of Oudh, also known as Awadh, was a significant event in Indian history. The annexation angered many Indians and is considered a cause of the Indian Mutiny (1857–58), the largest rebellion against British rule. The Indian Mutiny is also known as the First War of Indian Independence
  • The British annexed Upper Burma on January 1, 1886, after many years of conflict and British interference in Burmese politics. The Viceroy of India, Lord Dufferin, announced the annexation. 
  • The annexation ended the Konbaung dynasty and Burmese independence. However, resistance to British rule continued for four years.
  • The British occupied all of present-day Myanmar after three wars, making the territory a province of British India on January 1, 1886.
  • After World War II, the British granted Myanmar independence in January 1948, after 62 years of colonial rule.

question: What is most significant regarding partition of Bengal in 1905? (UPSC Prelims 1984)

option_2: The English established that they were strong people
option_3: Muslims were separated from other people
option_4: This paved the way for involvement of people in national movement
solution_text:
